author: Rick J

text:
Ahh, the Buick's fake vents... the story is a stylist put fake vents, along with tiny flashing lights on his 1948 Roadmaster. General Manager Harlow Curtice just loved them and had them added to the '49 (minus the lights). They've just been a sort of unofficial trademark on most years ever since... sort of like the driveway oil stain under any British car.

BTW, a friend once told me someone wrote Buick a letter asking what they were called and finally got a letter back saying, "Stratocruiser Ventiports." The real name, however, is "Cruiser-line Ventiports." 

And now you know - wait for it - the REST of the story. (Tip of the hat to the late, great Paul Harvey).Ôªø

text:
Good point on new tire on AWD. Learned this last week when wife's car got a flat. Tire shop wouldn't replace just the one, said had to be all 4 or maybe 2 depending on what owners manual says.  Manufacturer service center said AWD should not be impacted but didn't want the risk on a vehicle only a year old.

I ended up ordering a new shaved tire from tire rack.  Simply measure your tires left on vehicle, call up their customer service, and order the tire in the depth you need.  Awesome service that I think more tire shops will pick on in near future with all these AWD vehicles.Ôªø

text: Agreed with every point except the headlights.  Their made of plastic because rocks and debree hit that low part of the car very often, and if they were made of glass they would crack all the time. I actually have a 2013 toyota venza and the headlights are plastic while the fog lights are glass. 2016 rolls around can you guess what shattered? The light housing! And then it lets water in and destroys the whole light assembly and you end up having to change the whole thing anyway! Have you ever had a cracked windshield, its rare because the windshield is usually high enough to where debrees dont hit it but in lower cars and sometimes taller suvs they can break from the smallest of pebbles! Even the hoods of cars will have dings in the paint.  Plastic is cheaper and a more durable material for that application.  üòäÔªø

text:
I can‚Äôt stand the infotainment crap in almost all new vehicles these days. Why the hell woild I want wifi in my car? Isn‚Äôt distracted driving bad enough already? Come on...all I want are simple electronics. 
And I completely agree with you about the HIDs and added LEDs. I remember driving on a rural road at dusk when I used to live in Kentucky, and behind me I saw the glow of two bright green circles following me. Kind of freaked me out, to be honest. I half expected that I‚Äôd be abducted by aliens. Turns out it was a ‚Äò90s Jeep Cherokee with green LEDs added. And HIDs, especially the kits that people put in themselves without adjusting the beam angle, are BLINDINGLY bright. Seriously, if you need two spotlights in order to see at night, you shouldn‚Äôt be driving at night...Ôªø

text:
I think electronics should be a last resort, not a first resort.  And don't get me wrong, my computer is one of the most important things I have, but it's not running the entire effin' house!
And I'd never want it to.  K.I.S.S.  Keep It Simple Stupid.

I got annoyed at some other guy on this site for saying how he "needed" GPS to go hunting.  I use a compass.  Not even a map, just a compass.
Is having a semi-auto rifle with fucking thermal vision just not enough over-kill?  Gotta bring a GPS, too?  Where's the challenge?  Where's the thinking?
I think we may actually be devolving.  If you don't use it, you lose it.  Well, people aren't using their brains anymore...Ôªø

author: KoopaXross

text: What Scotty and most don't understand about the reason for the large grill is it is there to hide the sensors.  All these new cars have countless sensors for the safety tech in the car and they are trying to hide it as best as possible.  Next time you're near a Lexus or any of the new cars with large grills see if you can locate the adaptive cruise sensor plate or the front camera for the 360 degree camera system or the lane keeping sensors or the parking sensors.  If the grill is done right you won't be able to locate most of those.  Even if the particular car doesn't have the features they make all the grills the same so it won't be so easy to tell one from another.  Low profile tires are not always a bad thing when done right I have 20s on my car and it rides just as good as stock.  Everyone that gets in my car says it rides smooth.  SUV's are practical useful and popular so it makes sense for all as companies to offer them as an option.Ôªø

author: R BICKERTON

text:
I thought I had an old soul, but you take the cake Scotty! You truly are a dinosaur. 

The Buick Envision (and all Buick models for that matter) have those fake vents to signify the number of cylinders that the car has. This is something that Buick has been doing since the 60‚Äôs, and is something they are trying to keep around for heritage‚Äôs sake. I expected you, of all people, to at least appreciate that. 

Secondly...why should we have glass headlight enclosures, exactly? The last time I checked, polycarbonate (‚Äúplastic‚Äù) housings have a certain amount of flexion, which allows them to absorb impacts with rocks and other objects without shattering, unlike glass. Your other objection to them is that they ‚Äúcloud‚Äù over time, which is actually the UV-resistant coating on the polycarbonate shell that is breaking down. But for $20-$30 and a couple hours of work one afternoon, the average consumer can fix this problem and keep it from happening for another decade or more. Isn‚Äôt that what you‚Äôre all about?Ôªø

author: Syed Shah Nawaz Ali

text: Thank goodness I'm not the only one who hates the SUV trend! I live in Cornwall which is a very popular tourist and retirement location, which is fine except they all drive either hire cars or the big 4x4s. Now on the main roads that's not really an issue, but as soon as you go off the beaten track you're screwed. Every local who doesn't work in agriculture or fishing will tell you to get a hatchback as they can easily get down those narrow lanes, as most of them have pull ins to let other cars pass, especially if you're willing to accept the odd small scratch here or there. However with the large SUVs that's borderline impossible, especially if they don't want to get too near to the hedgerows. It's even worse with hire cars as they clearly don't want to scratch them at all. But to top it all off I've driven SUVs myself and they're about as exciting to drive as watching paint dry. I love my little Ford it's just so peppy and fun to drive. Plus all the parts are so cheap and easy to replace it's unbelievable. I miss the days when I was growing up when everyone had Golf GTis or other hot hatchbacks. They were so goodÔªø

author: Symbolic AcclaimedTM

text:
The main problem I have with modern, computer managed engines is that while they operate very efficiently and produce low emissions when they are new and all their components and sensors are functioning properly, when a component goes bad, the OBD2 system is piss poor at identifying the failed component, many times doesn't even recognize that the engine isn't operating properly, and, in some cases, the computer's corrections to poor emissions exacerbate the problem.  OBD2 came out in '96 IIRC and is still the standard today.  It is disgraceful that the industry is still running firmware rooted in a 33 year old standard.

First off, manufacturers should provide USB test ports or bluetooth conectivity on their Engine Control, Brake Control, and Transmission Control Modules so that they can be fully tested using a laptop, tablet, or smartphone.

Secondly, manufacturers should be required to make software or apps to test these modules available for free.

Third, manufacturers should be required to make all factory service manuals and technical bulletins available online for free.

Fourth, all model years of a manufacturer's vehicles should be graded on their emissions every year.  In states like CA where vehicles must undergo smog testing every two years, the state should make aggregated test results available to the pubic and should include failed tests in the results.  For example, one might look up the test results for a 1997 Ford Mustang equipped with a 4.6L V8 and see what percentage of such vehicles passed smog testing and what their average emissions were each test year.  This would give the state, car buyers, and manufacturers valuable feedback on how well these engines, their control modules, and the various sensors were designed and built.

My thought is that a modern, computer controlled, fuel injected engine has very low emissions when new, but as it ages, certain sensors and components begin to wear and develop errors that are within the allowable thresholds of error for the ECM and do not cause a check engine light, but do allow increased emissions and possibly even a poorly running engine.

Fifth, the standards for vehicle emissions controls need to be revised.  I'm not sure to what extent manufacturers have improved their improved their engine management approaches over the years because I'm still driving a '97 Mustang.  I find it particularly disturbing that each four-cylinder bank of my V8 relies on one oxygen sensor upstream of the Cat to determine if the computer should lean or enrich the A/F mixture to that bank of cylinders.  Suppose one of those four cylinders has a partially clogged fuel injector and the other three cylinders are operating perfectly.  The computer detects that the bank is running lean and richens the A/F mixture to all four cylinders.  Now I'll have three cylinders all running a bit too rich and the bad cylinder still running lean.  This results in much higher hydrocarbon emissions that the cat has to burn off, will damage the cat more than before the "correction" made to the A/F mixture, may result in more tailpipe emissions, and results in the engine running worse and decreased MPG.  Similarly, if the bad cylinder had a loss of spark due to a fouled plug, a bad plug wire, or a bad coil, the computer will errantly enrichen the A/F ratio with the same results.  The obvious solution is that the A/F ratio should be controlled individually for each cylinder.

The downside is that now the car has to be built with a header that has an O2 sensor on each downpipe and the PCM has to run eight channels of A/F ratio control instead of two channels.  This will increase vehicle cost for the extra O2 sensors, wiring, the more complex PCM, and the header.  It may also pose packaging problems to fit in the headers.

The upside is that if one cylinder has a problem, it is more easily detected and reported, the computer can effect a correction on only the bad cylinder(s), and the problem can be more easily diagnosed and corrected resulting in fuel savings, a better running engine, less damage to the Cat, and lower tailpipe emissions.  That is a tradeoff that I, as a consumer would be happy to accept.Ôªø

text: I have to disagree with the SUV trend. SUVs (or rather CUVs these days) are not the same vehicles as they used to be. My 2016 Rav4 gets better gas mileage than my 2009 SX4 used to get and that car was 3/4th the size of my Rav4. If gas prices really went high up, people will simply go for smaller crossovers like Honda HR-V and Hyundai Konas. text:
Great points Scotty!

The terrible protection on the front of vehicles today is horrible. 

Your comment on everything is an SUV is so true as well. I drive a Honda Accord V6 because I want great gas mileage. 

Excellent point on the spare tire issues too. The run flat tires are the worst! My Honda Odyssey came with them and they were terrible. They only lasted about 25,000 miles and to replace one tire was over $300! I ended up buying Acura MDX wheels and put regular Michellins on it.

Your comment on the low ride tires is true too. My Honda Accord has 19 inch wheels, and it looks great but holy hell it does make the ride harder. I only have 28,000 miles on the car so far, but I am thinking about when the tires wear out to buy 18 inch wheels and sell the 19 inch. 

Your comment about the fake exhausts drives me nuts! I love the fact my Honda Accord V6 has a true dual exhaust.Ôªø

text: No manual transmission option.  I can't believe these are getting phased out and it's all a marketing/profit scheme.  A few years ago I gave a ride to my boss who owned a lambo. So I asked him what he had in his lambo because I can't imagine driving one of these cars with an automatic and he tried to explain that he uses paddles on the steering wheel. text: I found that hazed headlights can be easily fixed with wet sanding.  And once restored can be kept crystal clear by regularly applying headlight polish. text:
The video should not focus on trends.  It should focus on the fact that real cars are becoming more and more scarce. This will continue until the day arrives for Self Driving Machines that will eliminate drivers on a large scale.  Every other junk running around is an SUV(Sport Utility Vehicle) that only 10% of the motoring public will ever use.  For those of you that don't know what a 'Station Wagon' was, here is a simple explanation: It was a Passenger Vehicle with an extended Roof Line creating large storage area.  They were known as 2 & 3 Seat Wagons that folded down when 9 passenger seating was not in use.

90% of today's  motoring public does not know what is a real car.  SUV's, Pick Up Trucks and massive Suburbans is what the public currently believes are beautiful cars. How pathetic.  
The only reason that Front/Wheel Drive cars were made was to increase the Manufacturers Net Profit per vehicle.  A FWD vehicle has a Production Cost of 40% less and a Rear/Wheel Drive vehicle.  The All Wheel Drive was developed to offset the dangers of FWD vehicles on slippery road surfaces.  These junks are not better than 4 Wheel Drive, but they cost 35% less to produce.

Everything produced today is to benefit the manufacturers' bottom line profit, however in order to achieve this reality it is necessary to dupe the masses about how great their junks are.  I have chosen to avoid discussing technical characteristics for obvious reasons. For those of you that do not have any automobile experience in the following categories, you cannot grasp the truth and reality:  Automotive Design and Engineering, Sales, Advertising, Automotive Mechanics and Excellent Driving Skills.Ôªø
author: BSA 650

author: Ceston Jackson

text:
Here's my list of things that bug me about modern cars:

-The daytime lights turn on with the gauges making you think that you 
are driving with your lights on at night. It may be bright up front, but
 the taillights are off. I always thought this was so stupid. 

- Like you said, the lack of a spare tire, some cars provide just a can with a substance 
that is supposed to plug the hole in the flat tire. What if that tire 
has a huge gash or a blowout? 

-Lack of a dipstick/filler tube for the transmission on most modern cars, making oil changes more difficult. 

- Lack of of a dipstick for something as basic as checking the engine oil.

- TOO MANY PLASTIC PARTS

-Some luxury cars /SUVs don't have a mechanical handle to open the 
tailgate. They rely on a sensor that you put your finger over to open 
it.

-Uncomfortable ride compared to large cars from the 70's to the early 90's. 

- I don't want to go thru a menu and a touchscreen  just 
to change the volume or the temperature of the cabin. Switches and knobs
 do a better job at this. 

-A question for Ford: Why did you get rid of the Crown Victoria? Why did you get rid of the Econoline? 

-This one is not as important but still matters: Lack of style. Today's 
cars are so bland, there are some exceptions like the Ford Mustang, 
Dodge Challenger and the Chrysler 300. Even theses are lame compared to 
cars prior to the 90s'Ôªø

text: You're wrong about needing to replace all 4 tires at least on my RAV4. The driveshaft clutch pack only is engaging the rear wheels when the car is first taking off and tapers off at around 25 miles per hour it is not a fully locked all wheel drive system. Different wheels are always spinning at different speeds as you go around curves so the system has to be flexible it can't be  locked  any high-speed to where the micro difference of tire tread would destroy the system.  I even got a head mechanic at the Toyota dealership to admit it. But if you need to tow your better lift all four wheels up.Ôªø

author: bigbangnone

text: Generalizations tend to be problematic.  Yes, German, Swedish and British imports are more expensive than other vehicles to buy, as well as service in the long run.  But they are simply not as troublesome as you describe uniformly.  Yes, there are duds, but there are vehicles which go a long, long while without failures.  And BMW is not the only manufacturer that supplies as standard equipment low profile tires and expensive wheels.  In 50 years of driving I've destroyed one tire on a pothole with its corresponding wheel, and the tire was paid for over 95% by its warranty.  Scotty, you do give excellent advice, but not everyone wants to drive a 10-12 year old car simply because it's inexpensive.  I'd rather have the surety of knowing the airbags will work (they don't consistently work after a decade or more) and I really do appreciate automatic emergency braking, blind spot monitoring, front and rear cross traffic warnings,  lane maintenance and several other features which really make me a better driver and those around me even safer, as well.  I appreciate the viewpoint you espouse but I don't believe generalizing that this is the 'way to go' applies universally.Ôªø

text: Please remember... SUV's didn't become popular until congress passed CAFE standards - the market exists on account of an artificial dislocation.   There are lots of people out there that did want better mileage after the gas crunch of the 70s/rationing in the early 80's, but they weren't willing to die for it:  we got an extra 5k highway deaths per year when CAFE went into effect, followed by the SUV craze.  It's survival, and... congress has no business designing automobiles.  The numbers got a little better, but only because of airbag technology. How many people remember the sales pitch of "crumple zones" in the 80's, as OEM's removed more and more steel from our cars?Ôªø

text:
SUV = stupid ugly vehicle. In Australia, we have adverts for SUVs, where the advertisers refer to them as a "practical vehicle". Practical? Sure, people can load them up with a lot of junk, but there are better vehicles for that. Compared to regular vehicles, SUVs use more fuel, they cost more to fix, most are too big to fit into regular parking bays, so the owners frequently obnoxiously take up more than one bay.
In Australia, there are a lot of people doing illegal vehicle modifications. Such as illegally "upgrading" their headlight bulbs to ultra-bright halogen bulbs (or those lights that emit various different colours), illegally adding other coloured lights, putting air foils on the back of their cars etc. or using those death spike bike racks on the back of their cars -the kind that could kill a person. They also block their license plate & rear light assembly. They're illegal to use, but people can still buy them. The same for those upright bars that attach to the front bull bar, so people can carry long poles or tubing on their roof. They're illegal too, but even some hire vehicles have them.Ôªø

author: slick67cuda

text:
Hi Scotty I really enjoyed your videos and we think almost exactly the same as I agree with most of your videos!

You hit the nail on the head regarding the plastic headlights (as well as other trends) is because of:
1) cheaper to manufacture and 
2) more expensive to maintain. 

For a manufacturer this is a win since they get to sell more:
1) complimentary products (anti fade, cleaner and service) as well as 
2) replacement parts (new headlights) for those that do not know how to defog them or old and cannot be bothered &
3) they can temper the plastic to have a shorter life compared to glass, causing the car to be obsolete earlier esp. if no replacements can be sourced once all these cars require replacing more or less the same time.

Unfortunately I do not see them going away especially when we have been conditioned this is the norm. I can only see them actually putting more unrequired complexity and more man made materials (less glass and steel) to control the product life (likey shorten it to increase rate of sales).Ôªø

text: Great video, Scotty. You're having to explain to the general public what most mechanics already know and practice. The reason that Toyota has sold so many little cars is that they just kept getting better at building conventional stuff better than anyone else. Unfortunately, now they have started adopting a more planned obsolescence philosophy. I still hope for the return to wire throttle cables, manual transmissions, manual parking brakes, manual window winders and wind wings. Part of the reason that GM has lost so many customers is that they adopted planned obsolescence. I hope that Toyota comes back to their senses and makes a simple set of cars again. Thanks for your video.Ôªø

text: @Scotty Kilmer - My parents purchased a 2013 Ford Fusion Titanium with 60k miles on it. The transmission failed so they brought it to Honest One Car Care where they told them it would cost a small fortune to replace the transmission. They paid out and the current transmission is shifting very hard out of second gear. They brought the car back to the shop and they said that the transmission is still working and the warranty only covers failed transmissions. Fast forward two weeks (yesterday) and their's transmission fluid in the driveway. My parents brought their car back in and now they claim it's the lines to the transmission cooler that's faulty and are requesting an additional $600.00 to replace. Shouldn't that be covered under the original repair and transmission replacement? Seems like they did something wrong and are trying to get my parents to fix it.Ôªø

author: Chris  Dickson

text:
I'm a 60 year old mechanic. I grew up working on '50s and '60s cars. My dad always had $200 cars, and I had to keep them going. Those were the days, when cars looked like cars, and were easy to work on. I rebuilt my first engine at age 12. A 200ci Ford straight six in a 1964 Fairlane. New cars are a nightmare to work on. People complain about how unreliable those old cars were. But we have reached the point where all the new computer technology on new cars makes them just as unreliable, if not more. I have a 2013 Chevy Sonic I bought about a year and a half ago, and have put 40,000 miles on. I have been working on it since I bought it. Every time I fix one thing, something else goes wrong. The check engine light is on again, I traced it to a bad thermostat. $80 for a new one, and you have to tear the whole top off the engine to get too it. 

To me by far the worst trend on newer cars is those huge wheels and tires with 1" sidewalls. Those came straight from the GHETTO. Cars with wheels like that are called donks. I wanted to buy a used late model Camaro, Mustang, or Challenger, but you can't get one without those donk wheels, so I gave up on that idea. I think I'll get a standard cab 2 door pickup, if I can find one. That is probably my next biggest issue. 4 door trucks. Those, and Crossovers are the dumbest, ugliest vehicles ever. I grew up with pickups on farms. Real pickups. 2 doors and an 8' bed. It gets really bad when someone takes one of those monstrosities and puts 30" GHETTO wheels on it. And yes, those huge grilles are hideous. GM ruined the new Camaro by putting those ugly things on it.Ôªø

text: Those huge gaping mouth grills are actually bad news because that huge area lets in every little rock, bug and some small birds. Those can find their way into your radiator mesh. Rocks and bugs can damage and clog a radiator within a few thousand miles if you live in certain areas of the country.  That's why I always attach an auxiliary screen in front of the radiator on all my vehicles. Any tough black screen will work for this. You'd be surprised at what collects on it after a summer.Ôªø

author: Logan Park

text: I complain about low profile tires all the time, in fact I bought a 2017 Camry instead of a 2018 because the 2017 Camry Le still had 16'' wheels, and the 2018's smallest were 17'', more tire not only rides better and protects your wheels, but they do better in snow and ice, because they flex more in the cold. I also hate the new front ends of these cars, but more because they don't have a real working bumper, this is even happening on more trucks, for example the new Tacoma. What ever happened to 5 mph bumpers, which I had a chance to test out in my 1995 Corolla, when I bumped into the back of a Mercury Sable, no damage done. If that happened in our new Camry, that big goofy grill would have shattered and so would my insurance rates. Mechanically, Direct Injection, CVT's , cylinder deactivation and Turbo's, are things that increase maintenance, and decrease the life of the engine. One more thing, I prefer cloth seats, but today's cloth even on pricey vehicles, are like the cheap seats in the past, I miss nice soft velour, my 2000 Jetta still had them, my ''08 Frontier somewhat has them, but my ''17 Camry's seats feel cheap, maybe this is the car makers way of pushing you toward  pricier leather.Ôªø
author: ron mortensen

text: you're not talking about 16" or 17" rim size, you're talking about tire height (the middle # in a tire size)Ôªø
author: Anthony Flores

text: @Anthony Flores Wheel size, measured from one size of the outer flange to the other, passing through the exact center of the wheel. The tire height you speak of, I'm not sure how to read, well I do know if two tires are the same size, but one requires 16'' rims and one 17'',  you lose a half an inch in sidewall thickness from outer tread to the rim, on the 17'', so on rough roads, or on lumpy ice, at cold tremps the rubber stiffens up and doesn't form as well to the road surface, causing either a rougher ride or less cold, ice and snow traction.Ôªø

text:
The supposed "Fake" exhaust tips aren't fake. They are simply valance mounted, the tail pipe of the exhaust empties into the tip just the same as if it was welded on the pipes. 
Mounting them into the rear valance makes it easier on a production line the tips are always "perfect" where as with cars that have tips welded or bolted to the exhaust pipes half the time they are crooked as hell.Ôªø

text:
The thing about the tyres is a load of rubbish. Modern awd systems are computer controlled and they can adjust for one new tyre across the axel . The old manual type system where not so forgiving. Scotty alot of people dont know that is based onthing 25 years ago vehicle have moved on. Its alway good practise on any car to change in pairs but punchures happen, tyre side wall damage happens manufactures know this so they build into there modern system torlerance. As you should never go below 3mm of tread for safety  it very rare you be in a situation of 3 and 9 mm across axles.

Run flat tyres are less than 10% more in price so they do not cost a fortune. In many countries there no cost difference.
Over the last 12 every car i have owned has not had a spare. Or did they have run flats. In this situation i agree with scotty that you should have at least a space saver wheel/ tyre on your car.
The compressors with repair fluid are ok for small nail type punctures. But anything else they are useless.
The small side walls on tyre, 40 going smaller i agree with scotty i had 255 18 35 tyres the slightest hole in the surface at any speed above 20 mph who slice the side wall openi had 12 tyres in 18 months never again would i have this tyre of side wall craziness.
The plastic head light there is also the safety aspect on impact.Ôªø

text:
One fine day in California, the rains came, and I was there. Coming south on I-15, I was descending the Cajon grade when I hit a pothole that shook my rig's wheel right out of my hands.

Didn't lose control, but I started seeing cars off on the sides of road, and started counting them, and within a couple of miles, reached a number of 47 stranded vehicles, all with 1-4 low profile tires, blown or with bent rims.

It was a glorious day to own wrecker services and tire stores.Ôªø

text:
Consumers are part of the problem,  if people did not buy these horrendous looking, and useless features, they would stop putting them on all their models. 

this also goes for fuel economy,   when gasoline was less than a dollar ( 90,s ) people bought gas guzzlers, then the prices went up to around a 1,50,  and people started buying economy cars.   after a few spikes to over 2 dollars a gallon, and they drop back down to 1.50, people started buying guzzlers.     now prices in the US are hovering around 2 bucks a gallon and everyone think that's super cheap,  because just they seen it spike up to close to 5 dollars a gallon.  

what I am getting at is,  that fuel prices could skyrocket next week,  and you are then stuck with a huge guzzling monstrosity that lowers in market value.  unless you are really taking your whole family up into the mountains every weekend,  do you really need a huge SUV to commute to work every day?Ôªø

author: egads2

text: Scotty this was a great list and I wholeheartedly agree with every point made, except one.  If you have 4WD/AWD and need a "new" tire, you do not have to replace all 4.  You can either get a used (but still recent manufacture year) tire with the same wear (can measure the inflated diameter) or you can get a new tire and have it shaved down to match, which usually costs about $25... or combine the two, get a used tire so it's cheaper and you're going to shave it down a bit more anyway so you don't miss the lost tread from being a used tire at all.  One last thing, if you nave normal mileage tires, don't replace any with those high silicone, high mileage tires as they will literally wear down half as fast to eventually become a different diameter, and you'll also have inferior, imbalanced traction (most relevant when braking) on that wheel.Ôªø

author: Lok Tom

text:
Sadly the consumers are the ones clamoring for SUV/ish vehicles.  Though I agree with sentiments shared about them, the Porsche Cayenne and the Macan are Porsche highest selling models and their SUV's outsell the rest of all other Porsche combined. 

The Jag F-Pace is the fastest selling Jag in history and is already their leading seller.  Maybe those numbers will slow down but I doubt it, I seen a few and it looks alright I suppose.   There's an association with larger vehicles be relevant to their owners own insecurities, ignorance, or just attitudes.  Dickinson, League City, and Texas City are pretty guilty of those assertions.  All I see here is lifted pickups with underglow led's, with giant low profile wheels and shiny suspension components meant for show rather than practicality.  

Whatever floats their owners boats I suppose.  so long as they don't drive like complete idiots and purposely take up 2 parking spaces.  Oh wait......... 

Regardless Consumerism is showing that they're asking for SUV versions of everything.  The manufacturers are only giving what the consumers think or believe they need or want.  I don't believe some of the manufacturers REALLY want to make SUV's, like the Cayenne/Macan/F-Pace but all the little princesses/princes think they do. 

You mentioned the URUS. In an interview with CNBC, Lamborghini CEO, Stefano Domenicali, said that sales and orders for the Lamborghini Urus, which starts at $200,000 but usually sells for $240,000 or more with options, have been "terrific."

"We were expecting a positive feedback from the customer, but not at the level we are receiving now," he said. "The reaction of the customer is really fantastic."

Specifically, he said the company will end 2018 with total production of around 5,000 cars ‚Äì more than 1,000 of which will be the Urus. By the end of 2019, Lambo will be producing around 8,000 cars ‚Äì with more than half being the SUV.

He said 70 percent of buyers of the Urus are new to the brand, meaning they have never owned a Lambo before. He said he is also surprised by how many of the buyers are women.

"We have seen an increase in female buyers for sure," Domenicali said.

I hate the trend too Scotty, and though Ferrari said they never would, well, Lambo said the same thing.  Maybe we'll see a Koenigseggseggseggsegg SUV, The Koenigsuvsuvsuvsuv.  A McLaren SuV.  Daddy has a lot of money, somebody has to spend it. Just ask Pastor John Gray's WifeÔªø
author: Snafu2346

text: I am a firm believer in variety and feel like there is still a market for sedans (which leaves me scratching my head when Ford announced they were abandoning cars). But you have to own an SUV or CUV to truly appreciate them and understand why they are popular. Especially if you have an active family lifestyle. Now I am not talking about monstrosities like Chevy Tahoe and Ford Expeditions, but one in the range of say a Honda HR-V to a Honda Pilot. I can tell you growing up, 80% of the cars my family owned were minivans and SUVs mostly. Even when gas prices went up in 2005 we simply downsized from a midsized body-on-frame Pathfinder to a compact unibody Grand Vitara. I learned to drive in SUVs and even my wife, who grew up in a country where the Ford EcoSport is virtually an Expedition here in terms of size, refuses to go with anything less than a CUV. Once you own one, the practicality, interior comfort, and peace of mind when driving in the snow is unmatched. I agree, I don't see SUVs going away. And it says alot when even Lamborghini, Bentley, and Rolls Royce are doing it. Even EV manufacturers are producing electrified SUVs. Rivian which is a widely talked about EV company like Tesla once was, their two launch models is an SUV and a pickup truck. GAC Motors, a Chinese car company is launching their GS8 which is a mid-sized 3-row crossover. The trend I don't understand are pickup trucks. I can understand them if you tow alot or actually use it for what its meant for like cargo, but people that just own them just because. For that, I'd rather the full SUV version and be able to store things inside a climate controlled cargo area.Ôªø

author: John Hermann

text:
Agree with all of these, but I do want to add touchscreens and ugly screens to the list. Every car maker is obsessed with slapping I-pads all over the dashboard. I get it, you can type destinations faster and browse menus quickly, but do you really need a touch display for the climate control?! 
The problem with a touch display is that you need to look at what function you are trying to touch. So you take your eyes off the road. My W211 E420 Mercedes has over 60 buttons throughout the dashboard and I know the placement of every one of those. I can change radio stations, answer a call, call someone, or adjust driving modes, or the climate control without looking at any of those things, because I can feel the buttons. 
The other problem with these dumb screens is that they produce too much light at night. Sure, they have a "night" mode, where it's dimmer and the colors are darker, but that thing still has a backlight that is shining right at your face. And if you have to drive through the night, it's a lot of unnecessary strain on your eyes.Ôªø

author: Kevin Pazos

text:
All-digital instruments on the dash. If any electrical or display malfunction happens, you're screwed because you won't see your speed and even though there IS an app for that (relies on your phone's sensors so your mileage per hour may vary - see what I did here?), can you see how full your tank is with any app? Nope. Temperature readings just in case? Nope. Critical system failure (check engine and whatnot)? Not really.

The other trend would be all gauges and instruments at the center of your dash. Not only it is distracting (Tesla and other brands seem to find it a smart idea... not without a HUD it isn't) because you have to look away from what's right in front of you, not so different than applying makeup on the highway while looking in the mirror as a driver, as far as distractions go.Ôªø

author: Vini SThrill

text: Here's one that's got to be near the top of the list:  HVAC controls that can only be accessed through the touchscreen display!  Many vehicles put some or all of the controls on the touchscreen menus, taking your eyes off the road for much more time unnecessarily.  Many manufacturers even split up some of the controls between knobs and the touchscreen.  Now this would make sense if all the commonly-used controls were knobs and the less-commonly-used ones were on the touchscreen menus like the heated/cooled seats.  But many haphazardly split up the controls like having a physical button for defrost, but having to access the menu to change to lower or bi-level airflow.  To me, that is too much work to do what used to be easy, it's not even more convenient, and is more likely to break!  Oh, sorry, but I guess it passes for 'cool' so they actually charge more money for this feature.  Unreal.Ôªø

author: JRC

text:
I wholeheartedly  agree. I want to buy a new reliable car as my retirement car. Something reliable like a Toyota or Lexus. But the once since 2014 or 2015 are so ugly I cannot imagine buying any of them. Now Honda has messed up the Civic as well. They have to learn that taking styling cues from the Lamborghini Aventador is not a good idea. Especially with all those dummy inserts that make drag worse. 

And don't start me on the skinny tires. There is no reason whatsoever for a normal car to have tires lower than a 60 series. Yet I am seeing 55 and 50 series, sometimes 45 series as standard equipment. Skinny tires should be left as an aftermarket item. 

If I do get a new car, I expect to have to a lot of bargaining to get the dealer to swap the rims and tires for 60 or 65 series. I looked at the Honda Fit and the base model has 65 series but the trim level I want has 55 series. 

Another thing I hate on the CUVs is phony skid plates which are often just paint. CUVs are not for serious off road use and the few who will use it for that can get an aftermarket one. I would want one that looks a lot friendlier like the old Rav4 or CRV.

When I do need to eventually go to buy a car, I maybe have to find a 2013 or earlier Toyouta or Lexus. Maybe a 2013 Lexus CT200H. I am not too worried about the battery any more after talking to taxi drivers here in Vancouver who use all types of Prius models. They get 500,000 kilometers on the batteries, replacing them at that distance whether the care needs it or not. They they scrap them at 1,000,000 kilometers. I can live with a hybrid that goes 500,000 km on the battery. It will outlast me.Ôªø

author: Frederick Toms

text:
Worst modern trend:

1) Engine start button , keyless entry ( so easy to steal , and I personally like the feeling of turning on the ignition with a key but wtv) 

2) Fake exhaust pipes

3) No buttons at all in a car ( not even for volume control !! ) , all touch screen ( ex : Tesla , with a huge 16-17 inch tablet in the middle of your dashboard and nothing else, doesn‚Äôt even look like a car anymore but a giant computer that u hop on ) 

4) Electronic Parking Brake 

5) Fake vent / grill

6) Turning signal that doesn‚Äôt stay up or down when u use them . It goes back to the middle positive even though the signal is still on . ( Ex : BMW, that might explain why many of them don‚Äôt bother using their signals ) 

7) Fake car ‚Äú voom voom‚Äù sound ( some literally come  with a tiny lil speaker installed in the back of the car to make that sound ) 

8) Keyless access cars that do not have a back up key access. ( Many cars that have keyless access  also come with a spare key that you can use to unlock the driver‚Äôs door in case your battery dies , emergency, malfunction or smt) . 

But unfortunately some don‚Äôt, and that is really a stupid & inconsiderate design . Just imagine ur battery dies , like 95% dead ( u can‚Äôt even unlock ur car with ur remote access or wtv) , and u wanna jump start ur battery but ur cables are in ur car , and u cannot have access to that bc ur car does not have a spare key for you to use in case the battery dies . So there‚Äôs no way for u to unlock the door and have access to ur car . So ur like stuck outside, waiting for the towing truck or someone that has jumping cables to help u out .Ôªø
author: Daniel Tran

text: Daniel Tran I think for the most part you are misinformed. Keyless entry is amazing, if someone wants to steal your car they will anyway so why compromise for thieves, would you buy an awful house so it doesn‚Äôt get broken into? Fake exhaust pipes are awful I agree and the point about Tesla is a massive hate of mine, it‚Äôs not safe at all. Fake engine sounds aren‚Äôt a big issue, they can‚Äôt usually be turned off and it‚Äôs pretty natural to remove the rattle sound of the engine, this is more so with the downsizing of engines. Electronic parking brakes are amazing aswell, especially for a manual car you simply put the car in gear and drive, once you stop take the car out of gear and if you have auto hold it will do that for you aswell so essentially you never have to touch the parking brake button or do anything other than drive and take your car in and out of gear, very simple with hill starts aswell, pretty much very VW has this now if not all and it‚Äôs something I must have! BMW will have it on all cars soon aswell once they release the new 1 series and other vehicles such as the 4 series. It‚Äôs simpler and safer because your car won‚Äôt roll and you can‚Äôt forget to put it on if you have auto hold for example. Cars with keyless entry always have a back up, in fact most cars with keyless entry usually have it as an option anyway so they have the normal ways but usually on the drivers for handle a part snaps off where there is a manual key hole.Ôªø
author: Chatta290

text: Chatta290 Hi ! Thx u for all those amazing infos u just gave here . I must agree u did change the way I look at electronic parking brake a bit lol, but u see .. the main thing that makes me not like them is not bc of safety reason really , but rather my PERSONAL preference of pulling up that thing and that sound that u hear (The whole mechanical process itself ) . And I‚Äôm sure a lot of folks out there doesn‚Äôt like that electronic parking brake for the same reason . Same thing with the keyless ignition system . I did mention that they were easy to steal, which is true; they ARE a bit easier to steal than cars with conventional access but I can ensure you, my friend, that IT IS REALLY NOT the reason why I dislike them. Some people, like me,  just like that whole feeling of turning on the engine with their key, the whole turning key mechanical process , and that‚Äôs okay . We each have our own preferences of the new technologies, and it is not about being ‚Äú misinformed ‚Äú but rather having our own preferences . And having different preferences definitely doesn‚Äôt equal to being misinformed .Ôªø
author: Daniel Tran

text:
Chatta290 

As for the keyless entry, I KNOW that some cars have backup key access and all that. That is why I mentioned above that MANY models have that backup access but unfortunately SOME DON‚ÄôT, and it is those that do not have that I dislike .  

My friend has a Tesla Model S . I respect his choice & preference. But that keyless entry once got him stuck outside pretty bad . You see , cars like model S , DO NOT have backup key access . I know that many many car models do , but SOME DON‚ÄôT. 

One time he went camping with his girl and for some reason , his battery was dead ( yes he charged it before leaving) . He couldn‚Äôt  get in the car with his keyfob to get his  jumpstart material and his phone. Luckily his gf had hers on her. He had to call me and I had to go all the way over there , to jump start his car . And it wasn‚Äôt easy job . Had to watch a video online on Youtube ( special thx to Mr @KmanAuto)  to understand how to even get to the battery cuz with Tesla , you need to have some sort of battery left to get access to the trunks ( which my friend didn‚Äôt) , and the way they make those units make it so much harder to find the battery and all ( it‚Äôs not the typical conventional design we all have ) . 

So all in all, I did really enjoy the elaborated & filled with details response that you gave above . Thx u very much for that. Always fun to discuss with folks online about cars and all that . But note that I did mention that I only dislike those FEW keyless units that didn‚Äôt provide any backup way to get in the car with no battery life left at all . And that not all of them do that, many do provide a backup key accessÔªø
author: Daniel Tran

Most cars will have these new parking brakes now though so I guess soon it‚Äôs on lying used cars that will have them, keyless entry in the UK is only really standard on cars such as the 7 series, not even the A8 or S Class have it, it‚Äôs not too popular because it‚Äôs a waste of money to pay for really. author: Eli Empire

text: @Chatta290 First, I didn't even try to be funny. Second, police reports about car thefts and results of ADAC tests is media to believe. And yes, you can steal any car with right tools and knowledge, but keyless entry made it easier than ever. You don't even need to reprogram anything, you just need to intercept the key signal and make it stronger. Recently, ADAC tested 237 popular European market models and found out only 3 of them are fully and 4 partially protected against a relay attack.Ôªø

text:
Most hated trends for me are (in no particular order):
1. Buying cars that are "blacked-out." Meaning the only color on the car is black, including the brand logo. 
2. Stuck on infotainment systems. They look ridiculous and show a lack of design implementation. 
3. Cars with turbos in them, right out of the factory. 
4. Cylinder deactivation. 
5. Modern shifters. Something that was once so simple has somehow become really complex. 
6. Cross-overs killing the sedans. I just want a 4 door car, that gets decent gas mileage while having a personality. Not a big, clunky, ugly cross-over.Ôªø

text:
The main reason cars have no spare is nobody changes tires anymore on the road.   Everyone has roadside service and definitely everyone has a cell phone.  
Now in the old days, I could change a tire with my eyes closed.  Many times you were forced to.  You had no way to contact anyone if you got stuck.  But today......I call the man.   
There is enough infrastructure available in modern society that one does not have to risk one's life changing a silly tire while cars and trucks wiz by at 60mph !!Ôªø

text:
Good trends I personally see are:
-The cheapest cars are more refined than ever.
-Using port injection with direct injection to keep intake valves clean.
-Pushrod and dual overhead cam V8's are alive and well.
-Modern tires have become so good even some all seasons offer good handling.
-Seat ventilation
-Simple manual shift modes for automatics.
-HUD.
-Touchscreens that sit on top the dash allow dashboard designs to look more sleek and straight. It really grew on me.Ôªø

text: I would add the general hideousness of the "robo" or "pimp mobile" look of all  the new cars.  You mentioned those ridiculous head light shapes.  I say the same for the tail lights and the overall shapes of the bodies with all the weird curves and low roof lines are just plain ugly.  They remind me of the leisure suits that were the rage in the 1970's. The new cars today are like the late 50's, early 60's and 70's--just gaudy.   What happened to the simple headlight, tail light, and clean lines like the 65 Ford Mustang.  Mercedes was the last company that maintained that simple and clean elegance.  Now even the SUVs' are getting weird.  I wouldn't buy any car later than 2008.  Actually, the FIAT and Volkswagen are better than most.  Too bad they are not mechanically sound.   Same for the Mercedes.  Wish I could put a Toyota power train into a earlier model Mercedes but #$%&fornia would never allow.Ôªø

author: Tenzin Smith

text:
@Tenzin Smith Cylinder deactivation is either all or nothing, to when you need the power, you can mash the gas and get the power you need, but it still takes a split second for the car to go, OK he wants power, lets give it to him, which decreases the responsiveness you feel through the pedal. 
Also I've noticed that in regular driving the car will cycle cylinder deactivation on and off several times as I'm driving. If I come up on a hill I need to give it more gas but again it takes that split second to give it to me. I'd personally prefer better responsiveness over gas mileage.Or at least have C D as an option instead of mandatory.Ôªø

text:
It's not true that you need to replace all 4 tires on a 4WD vehicle. I had to change 2 tires on a 4WD Honda CRV, because the previous owner did not rotate tires at all. All Honda documentation says that you need to only change tires in pairs.
And a Costco store refused to sell me 2 tires for this CRV on the same basis. I had to go to Honda dealership and they confirmed that this is just money extortion on part of tire manufacturers and resellers, and they happily sold me 2 tires for that CRV. Tire manufacturers scare poorly educated customers into buying all 4 tires, because "something really, really bad going to happen and you are going to die".Ôªø

I hate electronic parking brakes

As I'm sure you know many all wheel drive SUVs operate in front wheel drive until the tire slip. I think all wheel drive has its uses even where it doesn't snow. It's really nice to be able to have traction coming out of a turn in the rain.

text:
I agree, I agree, I agree!!!  
We have a 2004 Lexus and said that if I had to replace it today it wouldn't be with a new Lexus.  I really like my car, I especially like the reliability, and I realize that the way a car looks isn't a necessarily an intelligent factor in choosing a car but I just don't like the new grills.
I also agree regarding the trend towards all of the SUVs.  I like my car and have read that manufacturers are going away from making cars (more money in SUVs and trucks I suppose).
More agreement on the low profile tires.  My car has them with a sport suspension... never again.  I have not had problems with tires or rims being damaged from potholes but they're more expensive and the ride isn't as smooth.  
We've also got an '87 BMW that I like.  It has the glass headlights that still look good - no cracks.Ôªø

author: Noah Vale

text: Let me educate you on fender benders since it seems you have never had one. Long story short, it already costs thousands of dollars. In 2012 I got cut off by a ricer looking honda civic, I slammed my brakes and I managed to avoid read ending the civic that cut me off. The car behind me, some older ratchet looking car, probably didn't have the best of brakes, didn't manage to stop in time and rear ended my bumper. His license plate was embedded into my bumper, there was a cut and a few minor points of impact. We exchanged insurance information (NY state) and filled a police report, and instead of heading to my scheduled psychology class I went back home. Days later and 2 quotes from two body shops we were awarded 1600$ from their insurance company. This was maybe 50% or so of what that 2006 nissan altima was worth, so obviously instead of having the insurance company pay the body shop we cashed out on the sum towards a new car.Ôªø
author: mad0uche

text: mad0uche I have literally handled thousands of auto claims.  The new designs imho are likely to significantly increase the cost of parts needed to fix a minor fender bender.Ôªø

author: Bullion Forever

text:
Rover in the U.K. got rid of the grill above the bumper when the SD1 was released in 1976. Engineers realised that there was sufficient cooling to the engine below the bumper and removing the grill would aid aerodynamics. It went on to win the European Car of the Year.

Move forward to the 90s and a trend had started to introduce old fashioned looking grills on the fronts of cars. Rover this time to look more "premium" decided to re-introduce the style of grills that they had used in the 50s and 60s. They were put on just for show and the trend has continued to silly degrees like you see on the Lexus. It's really a step back for engineering. Tesla have the right idea and have completely deleted any sign of one, due to the car being electric.Ôªø

author: Enderboy 64

text: Great video Scotty. I agree with all your points. I suspect the huge grilles aren't just for "styling" but because otherwise you'd have more painted bodywork at the front which picks up stone chips and will cost the manufacturers money in warranty repairs. I've just bought a car with led headlamps and have had a few people flash their lights at me; unfortunately,  they're self adjusting so I can't do anything about it. One other trend I hate about new cars is the touch screens on dashboards. You have to take your eyes off the road for too long to operate them and they are just a distraction. Even if you have loads of buttons, if you own a car you get to memorise where they are so you can find them without looking. One other trend that affects us here in Europe more than North America is to fit tiny engines with turbos. The fuel consumption is never as good as the official figures because to drive at a decent speed you need to make use of the boost a lot. So far only Mazda seem to be bucking this trend.Ôªø

author: Mike J.

text:
Happy New Year.
Also should mention too many electronics such as water pump, brakes, steering, transmission shift, steering assist, etc. Hybrids have electronic steering assist. Toyota Camry Hybrid had some issues with steering fail on 2007 (first year) models.
Some owners of Honda's 2019 Odyssey have had issues with shifting into park while driving on the highway. May be caused by sliding door latch failures. Computer thinks the door is open and automatically puts the transmission in park.
I agree with you on low profile tires and big mouth grills that look like a drooling imbecile.Ôªø

text: I definitely see the arguement against the push button starts / smart fobs but Scotty mentions a few videos ago how you can just lock the door with the power locks button to avoid frequency skimming. Ironically, I already knew and practiced this. However, I must say the pros outweigh the cons as I absolutely love that I never have to take the fob out of my pocket. I don't know if all manufacturers offer the following features but with my Nissan you can unlock the door by pressing a tiny button on the door handle which is much more convenient than one may realize if never had that "luxury", same goes for not having to use a key to start it. Also, it is impossible to lock the fob (the keys) in the car as it unlocks immediately if you close a locked door and the fob is in the car for some reason and the car makes rapid high pitch beeps at you to let you know. I can leave the car running with the doors locked on hot days (gets 90's+ in the Summer and below freezing in Winters where I live) when I run into the gas station so my car stays cool or warm, my fuel door is electronic and always remains locked unless the doors are unlocked, which I'm sure some of you have had to reopen your door and pop the fuel door after having already gotten out of the car or after running into paying for gas, but with mine you just press the button on the door handle and then the fuel door becomes unlocked and it is opened by pushing on the fuel door, not pulling. The fob allows me to roll my windows down to cool the car down if it's been in the sun which helps immensely. However, for $100 I added a plug n play auto start via a t harness to the obd2 so I rarely use that feature now and I get in an ice cold car. I love it tbh. But like I said there are good arguements to be made against it like cost of replacement, theft, more things that could break, etc. No issues for me so far.Ôªø
author: J R

text: @J R on my car, you have to use the fob to lock the doors, you can't lock them with the button and then close the door. of course, I seriously doubt anyone is following me around and stalking me for the frequency of my key fob to steal my smart fortwo.Ôªø
author: chief tp
kauske

text: @chief tp I agree, I think the key fob skimming is a bit parinoid or maybe more of an issue in other cities. However, I live in a suburb of St. Louis which isn't necessarily a safe city (often #1 murders in the U.S. and top 5 for sometime) and to the best of my knowledge this sort of skimming theft is rare. The tiny button on the exterior door handle is also a safe guard against the skimming but I highly doubt many are using it for that feature and I doubt dealers tell buyers to use it that way. Unless someone knows differently because in order to use that feature the fob is "sensing" you next to the car but the actually button is electronic so... can that be skimmed the same way??? I'm unsure. Also, if ever you're ever attempted to be car jacked you can just turn the car off via the push button on the dash, get out and say here's the keys buddy as you throw the fob on top of the gas station, into the bushes, or just simply away from YOU, etc.Ôªø

I'm a fan boy lol!  Sorry!Ôªø

text: @kauske I agree but if they're that into it they can take any car so it's really a mute point isn't it?  I mean if there's a shop wanting your model car, they know how to get it. So maybe I'm wrong. Btw, God you guys are gonna hate me... I also have a hidden gps tracker (aftermarket) on my car so I know where its going or sitting and for how long in real time via Google Timeline, if that should happen. But maybe if they're advanced enough they'll know how to scramble the gps signal?  I'm uncertain.Ôªø

text: For 30 years in Argentina, Ford manufactured their Falcon sedan model and except for a minor change in 1962 they always vetoed any kind of redesigns keeping the model's body always in its original form. For this reason, the only changes that they did do were internal or mechanical ones (in 1973 they actually corrected the steering wheel position). By the end of its run they even introduced a motor that consumed less gas. That is why this model still have a big following that is devoted. That does not mean that Ford didn't make other mistakes, the errors with the Sierra cost them big.Ôªø

text: What a beauty of a video. Scotty you said something sublime in this one. Form should follow function not the other way around. I used to own a Pontiac Acadian. Man that thing took a beating. It was a standard and I was able to get 350 kilometers out of it and then sold it to some university guy who used it for 2 more years as his beater. I used to go to the junkyard and drop 40 bucks Canadian and what ever I could could carry out unassisted was included. I got just about everything for that car except a new engine block. Okay sorry about the tangent. Back to function. It was a terrible boxy design but one day my wife and I went on vacation and strapped on a wedge shaped luggage carrier to the roof. It rode like a charm. So much so I kept it on for the duration of the ownership of the vehicle. Yeah I took my verbal humps from my buds but it was my status symbol. I'm a function over form guy anyway. Made it real easy to find my car in the busy malls. Everyone seems to be enamelled (pun intended) with form. Well for me, give me something well engineered for the purpose and screw the beauty. Good engineering takes time.Ôªø

text: These are all seriously irritating!! In five years, the thing will be "micro-grills". You missed a biggy IMO. Cars are starting to ship with a "feature" of automatically shutting off the engine in traffic (like at a stop light) and re-starting when you hit the gas. This puts a treamendous extra burden on the alternator, which should be re-designed for the heavier duty cycle, as well as the battery, which normally has to start the car maybe a couple times in a driving day, now may have to start the engine, DOZENS of times, not to mention what this means for the engines operating conditions. All of this extra expense and failure modes to perhaps save 1 MPG under SOME conditions.  Thank your government and draconian CAFE regs.Ôªø

author: CentralCoastCamper

text: You dont have to... Use the gear wrench magnetic socket tool theres enough room to get the plugs out without removing the intake manifold. I've done many Avalons and Solaras. If you take off the obd2 port and the pcv hose it makes it easier but even that isn't entirely necessary. I can do all 6 in 20 minsüëçÔªø
author: Anonymous

text:
@Anonymous No, you can't. You have to remove the entire air intake manifold to even get to the spark plugs. The spark plug coils are directly under the manifold, and the manifold covers all of the sockets. Unless you drill giant holes in it, there is no way you are getting a socket anywhere near your sparkplugs without removing the air intake manifold.

My 08 es350 has the same thing. Pretty stupid design. The front 3 are easy to get to and take all of 5 minutes to change. The back 3 take 30 minutes to an hour just to get to them. And there's so many god damn bolts. You can't even see the back brackets that you have to remove.Ôªø
author: megamixa

text:
@megamixa I just did the plugs in my Avalon over the summer  you dont need to take it off. My best friend put 300k on a 2000 solara and he never removed the manifold either.

You can get the coils out and the plugs there is room. The center one pulls out to one side then pulls out bottom first if I remember correctly. I believe theres also you tube videos of people doing as well but I can tell you 100% you do not need to take off the manifold.Ôªø
author: Anonymous

text: @megamixa Gear wrench 80546 magnetic swivel socket is what I used and it gives you enough room to pull the plugs. Its actually very easy.Ôªø
author: Anonymous

text: And after all that the plugs were fine. Dont even mess w plugs in these newer carsÔªø

text: One I've come up with recently since buying a new car are running lights that you can't turn off unless you turn the engine off. So what's the problem? Picture, if you will, sitting in a car park waiting for someone, and it's hot. So you run the engine to run the aircon. And so the running lights are also on and you can't turn them off. So you are drawing attention to yourself at a time when being the grey man might be desirable. Another bad trend are chirps, bells and farts from the car computer to tell you you put your keys in the ignition but haven't closed the door, even if you've got the door open for a reason, and you can't shut it off. I don't mind the safety warning, but there should be a way to shut if off, or shout "Acknowledged!" or "Shut the hell up!" to stop it.Ôªø

text: @joe pierson True.  So lets pick two vehicles where a 4 cylinder is an option.  The Chevy Traverse and the Chevy Impala.  The Traverse gets 18/27, the Impala gets 18/28.  Now the two vehicles are essentially the same Joe. Where I live - I have tried multiple cars on a 600 foot climb in the Winter with snow tires.  Cannot get up the mountain in a Camry, Accord, or Mazda 6.  A FWD Saab 9-3 struggles and can sometimes make it.  The AWD cars have no problem. So no, a FWD car won't work for me.Ôªø
author: Sam S

text: @A Team Good point.  I looked also at the Travere (18/27) and Impala (19/28) with FWD and four cylinder engines - they get the same mileage. Where I live, I get a ton of snow and I have a 600 foot climb to my home.  I had multiple FWD cars with snow tires - all get stuck in the winter.  So now I have an AWD (and slightly lower mileage) but I can get home - which is important to me.Ôªø

text: I have a 2002 Chevy Impala with the 3800 V6. There is a very loud squealing under the hood, it sounds like it is coming from the alternator, but I have replaced it twice to see if it was the noise and it does not appear to be. Any ideas?Ôªø
author: Brendan Geldersma

text: Might just need a new belt.. if it's stretched so much that the tensioner is maxed out, it'll be too loose and slip and squeal, especially when you turn the wheel making the power steering pump work harder putting more load on the belt. If the belt is good, it could be a seized tensioner.. i think those ones just use a spring loaded pulley.. you can put a socket and breaker bar on it and pull it up to check it's moving freely.Ôªø

text: Exactly. My 2001 Dodge 2500 Ram Diesel 4X4 is older, but low mileage. Having problems with the antilock brakes not working. I can live with this but now the speedometer has quit. Looking at close a thousand dollars using an OEM part. Ludricrous! Why does the speedometer have to be tied into a computer controlling the brakes? What's wrong with the old gear and cable system?
